intro: Acaena rahuensis, commonly known as the New Zealand bracken, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and spiny bracts. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. Its fruits are dry, indehiscent capsules that contain several seeds. Acaena rahuensis is often found in forest margins and rocky areas, where it thrives in moist, shaded conditions.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena rahuensis is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the central and southern regions. This plant typically grows in coastal areas and on rocky slopes. It is commonly associated with the lower and middle elevations of the region. Acaena rahuensis is part of the native flora of the New Zealand's coastal ecosystems.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena rahuensis was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. The plant has since become naturalized in certain regions of the country. It is commonly found in coastal and subalpine areas where it thrives in well-drained soils. However, it is considered a potential weed in some parts of its introduced range.
